keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum in Paris experienced a major heist on October 20, 2025, where thieves stole nine high-value historical artifacts from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes.
Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem and necklace from Napoleon’s second wife Marie-Louise, and a reliquary brooch and diadem originally owned by Empress Eugénie.
The emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise was purchased by the Louvre in 2004 for €3.7 million and is one of the most historically significant pieces.
The sapphire jewelry set, possibly linked to Marie Antoinette, was acquired by the Louvre in 1985 after being in the Orléans family for generations.
The reliquary brooch, containing the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, was acquired by the Louvre in 2008 for €6.72 million, reflecting its immense cultural and historical value.
The diamond bow brooch, originally part of a 4,000-stone belt worn by Eugénie during royal events, was transformed into a standalone piece and later acquired by the Louvre.
One of the stolen items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered outside the museum, though it was damaged during the theft.
Art recovery expert Arthur Brand described the theft as a 'national disaster' for France, emphasizing that the items represent national pride and are likely to be melted down and sold.
The thieves used motorcycles to escape and broke into two high-security display cases, indicating a well-coordinated, high-risk operation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 20, 2025, a coordinated heist occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris, where thieves stole nine historically significant artifacts from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes. Among the stolen items are a sapphire diadem and necklace from Napoleon’s second wife Marie-Louise, a reliquary brooch and diadem from Empress Eugénie, and other royal jewelry linked to the Orléans and French royal families. The stolen items were crafted by 19th-century Parisian jewelers and represent centuries of French imperial history and cultural pride. One of the stolen items, Eugénie’s crown, was recovered near the scene but was damaged. Art expert Arthur Brand described the theft as a 'national disaster' for France, warning that the thieves will likely dismantle and sell the jewels, melting the gold and silver. The Louvre, which acquired many of these items in the 2000s, has lost irreplaceable pieces of national heritage. The heist underscores the vulnerability of cultural institutions and the global significance of preserving historical artifacts.
